content.webTitle: 'Silence is just as bad': Adam Jones on racism and why athletes must speak out

fields.headline: 'Silence is just as bad': Adam Jones on racism and why athletes must speak out
fields.bodyText: Baltimore Orioles center fielder Adam Jones has called on athletes to speak out for what they stand for amid a turbulent month that saw the five-times All-Star targeted by racist slurs during a game at Fenway Park. Jones, 31, made the remarks in a wide-ranging interview with Yahoo Sports published on Tuesday. “As athletes, we do have to be censored in a certain way, but at the same time, if there’s a big issue, and it’s something you stand for, you’ve got to speak out,” Jones said. “Because if you’re worried about the backlash, I think silence is just as bad.” Jones said he wants to use the Fenway Park incident as a platform to discuss racial inequalities in baseball and society at large. “I’m not afraid of the backlash, because it’s the truth,” Jones said. “It’s my truth through my eyes. We all have our own truths. How we were raised – that’s our truth. Growing up in San Diego, or California in general, it’s a very liberal state. I grew up with blacks, whites, Mexicans, Filipinos. Everything was diverse. My class wasn’t predominately anything. Playing sports, it was diverse. My neighborhood was diverse. “The worst thing is when people say, ‘I don’t see color.’ I think that’s the dumbest thing. Unless you’re colorblind, you see color. You may choose not to think of the other things that come with color, but you see color. At the ballpark in San Diego, you see the diversity. LA, Arizona, San Francisco, both Texas teams. You just see so much diversity. Growing up like that, I always assumed the rest of the United States, the rest of the world, was like that.” Jones gave the interview while in Kansas City to announce his $20,000 donation to the Negro Leagues Baseball Museum, only two weeks after he said he was called the N-word and had a bag of peanuts thrown in his direction in Boston. When asked about naysayers like former Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling, who said that Jones was lying about the racist heckling he endured during the 1 May game (which prompted an apology from the team and a lifetime ban for a fan involved), Jones doubted the outspoken conservative’s ability to sympathize with his experience. “Schilling is over there with his rants,” Jones said. “He just wants an outlet. Somebody will take his call, take his rants. He can keep them for himself. Because he’s never experienced anything like I have. I’ll stick with what [Mark] McLemore said about it: Schilling, hell of a career. But he’s never been black, and he’s never played the outfield in Boston. Last year, Jones claimed major league baseball players were loath to join in on Colin Kaepernick’s national anthem protest because “baseball is a white man’s sport”, with African American players comprising just 8% of last year’s rosters league-wide compared to 68% in the NFL. Jones expounded on those remarks in Tuesday’s interview, pointing to a lack of diversity in the game’s management and executive positions. Yet his response took a firmly political tack when it came to baseball’s languishing participation numbers among African American youth. “It’s bigger than just baseball,” Jones said. “And this is what I believe: Baseball always has been a father-son game. You play catch with your dad-type game. The last 30 years, especially in California with the three-strike policy that (Ronald) Reagan and (George HW) Bush – the three-strike policy in general – there aren’t as many black fathers out there to play catch. The mother is turned into a single mother. She doesn’t have the time, the energy, because she just worked a double. “The availability of the parent is not there to play with the kid. The neighborhood is fine, but baseball is generally taught from father to son, even if the dad didn’t play. I just think that with the African-American father not as involved with the life of the kid – that’s way bigger than baseball. “It’s real life tying into sports.”
